columbia is very gay

A stunning original world of retro-sci-fi technology and gorgeous scenery. A cast of fully fleshed-out, memorable characters who deliver real emotional impact. A great villain and a greater monster. New and thrilling ways of traveling and changing the world around you. A story twist most people won't see coming.

The combat does exhibit a wonderful sense of growth, however. You find various clothing items that grant you additional passive buffs, such as turning enemies you leap on into human torches. You spend the coins you pilfer from corpses and cash registers on vigor and weapon upgrades, though you ultimately must pick and choose the direction you prefer, since you can't afford every possibility. 

The cons of this game are that it uses checkpoints rather than manual save points, which is pretty annoying since you have to pass a certain threshold in order to be able to save. But it is still a great game to play.

The conclusion I came to for this game is that BioShock Infinite is something special that no one should miss.

This has to be one of the best games I have ever played. The story was beyond phenomenal and gameplay was so amazing. Having played the previous Bioshock games, I can safely say that this one is the best, the DLC to this game seals the story and ties all the loose ends and gives one of the biggest twists in video game history. It was captivating, violent, and really really fun, if you havent played the Bioshock games, do it quick, you must play them all because this game is the cherry on top, the perfect ending. 10/10

I came in skeptical since people have divisive opinions regarding infinite compared to the earlier Bioshock games and I'm not the biggest fan of fps games. However I was pleasantly surprised after playing it. 

I highly recommend this game. Although, it's not your typical shooter since its more story oriented and probably doesn't have the best gameplay mechanics, the story is where it really shines. The character development is great and story is definitely one of the best I've seen in a while. 

I've finished bs2 and I'm going to play the original now! :)
Se pasan las horas volando.Hecho de menos el llevar mÃ¡s de 2 armas y un mapa.10/10

Bioshock Infinite is at its strongest when it is about the city Columbia, its society, and the people that inhabit it. Its themes on the dangers of white nationalism, racism, classism, and the horseshoe theory on diametrically opposed extremism is engrossing, however the plot shifts away from this in the second half of the game to focus more on a more personal plot about the two main characters, the multiverse, and how to deal with the consequences of ones actions. You will see the latter half and ending as one of the greatest stories for a game ever written or a pretentious plot line that eats itself without really resolving anything. The same can be said about its DLC "Buried at Sea" which is duology that is set in Rapture before the civil war that destroys the city before the first game. While the first episode is an interesting examination of Rapture society before its fall, the second episode relies on you to the player to be brain dead in order to accept the stupidity of the characters actions. The conclusion to the second episode is a dark, gloomy end that invalidates the themes of the first game to begin with and in fact validates Andrew Ryan's extreme isolationist beliefs.

The gameplay while simplified over the second title is enjoyable, visceral, and fast paced. The new powers they have added to the game make combining abilities easy and fun. The game comes with a DLC mode called "Clash in the Clouds" for those that wish to play an arena like mode to fully take advantage of the gameplay and test their abilities against every increasing difficult waves of enemies. The artistry of the game is amazing with a great attention to detail that only fails when it comes to the character models that populate the world itself. The areas you visit are varied and truly stand out from one another that exemplifies the World Fair in the sky theme that they were going for.

Bioshock Infinite is not a perfect game but one people should play due to its artistry, strong voice acting, and examination of American Exceptionalism, racism, and lesser known American history events such as the Boxer Rebellion and Wounded Knee. The story may be amazing or infuriating depending but it is unforgettable nonetheless.

This game was a great piece of art. Perhaps not gameplaywise since it is just another steampunk fps game, but the visuals, and a story - extremely well made. The Flying City of Columbia is well, gorgeous. Like it was from a dream. To be fair, for it's time - the year 2013 - the graphics are absolutely great. Now if it comes to the story, while playing you will encounter some cutscenes you will not be able to understand at first, but trust me, the story is so well made, that everything will make perfect sense at the end. And don't make me even get started at the plot twist which happens well into the game. To sum up, totally recommend this piece of art to everyone who can appreciate it.

best game

One of the best story-oriented shooters I've played. The combat is super unique and fun as you combine both weapons and special abilities for really satisfying combos. There's also tons of abilities, weapons, and gear so you can play in whatever style you want, as well as DLC to keep the game worth your while. Overall, if you're looking for a fun singleplayer shooter, this is probably one of the best choices out there.

So it doesn't have that eerie nostalgia the first game has. However, as far as gameplay goes, this is the best Bioshock game in the series. Not often can an established series go in such a wildly different direction and live to tell about it. Bioshock did just that and executed brilliantly. I always thought Bioshock's combat was its weakest component but the rework of it in this title blows me away every time. Incredibly fun. The introduction of critical shots and the rework of the plasmid (vigor) system feels like how it should have felt all along. 10/10

[h1]A world building so vivid; less so from bloated writing[/h1]
Much like the first game, Bioshock Infinite manages to bring a fresh, new start to the franchise by changing the environment anew, moving from the dystopian underwater city to a seemingly utopian city in the clouds with a working society. You play as Booker Dewitt, a mercenary who sets out to a secluded cloud city Columbia, to retrieve a girl called Elizabeth and pay off his debt to shady people.

The world built in previous Bioshock games were already on a high-ticket level, although Infinite breathes a fresh air with its new premise. The introducing chapters on the story certainly shows the strong side of the world building, augmented by the game's engine for stunning graphics, for those looking for a great showcase of lighting, water effects and level design. The amount of NPC models, peripheral dialogues and richness of the observable 1910's American society presented manages to pull me into the world full of life. It's worth mentioning how much effort the devs put into the way my companion Elizabeth behaves to the surrounding level parts, even as vividly during the idle moments.

Infinite has gotten some combat system overhaul; the main thing is that you will be limited to carrying only 2 firearms with you and rely on whatever drops or environment that you'd like to switch to. For that reason, some gamers have a beef with such a degradation from previous titles. Personally, I'm not bothered by this added gun management factor, considering that the game is already has got the ammo and weapon balance right throughout the story mode.

I might recommend Bioshock Infinite for its style, graphics and gameplay, but it still suffers from the overambitious use of lore and complexity of writing that robbed the previous Bioshock games the intriguing value of experience. I still find it hard to care about the plot here as well, although I must give positive points for the thought-provoking twist during the final chapters that tie in with the prequels. In the future, I might see myself come back to this game by watching on Youtube for references in the future.

Amazing game, not quite as good as Bioshock 1, but still an amazing experience.

Bioshock Infinite
By: Irrational Games
2013 (2022)

You are Booker De Witt a late 20th century-style bad ass. You are hired to save Elizabeth, who is being held captive in a tower in the flying city of Columbia. 

Bioshock Infinite is a run and gun type game that likes to focus way more on the gameplay than the story. The gameplay is very boring and almost made me want to quit playing entirely. You can choose between four different assault rifles, two different rpg's and maybe two or three pistols that you can use. There are spells you can cast, called 'vigors', which are actually pretty fun to use. However, none of the enemies require you to use a vigor to defeat them, so you end up not using them at all.

The graphics are fine and have a fun cartoonish look to them without making the game feel goofy. The aesthetic of the game is pretty unique and quite appealing. Columbia is a gorgeous, colourful city suspended high above the clouds which makes it feel fantastical and impressive. However, at times the game gets pretty grimm and manages to unnerve you, but then resorts to jump scares instead of actual horror, which is disappointing.

There's a great variety of shops to be seen on the streets but not once did I come across an apartment. This makes the locations you go to feel more like levels and less like a cohesive world where people actually live.
The backtracking in this game is annoying as hell: You defeat all the enemies, get to the end of the level, only to be told you have to go right back to the beginning and then back to the end again to progress to the next area. 

The last 30 minutes of the game were the most enjoyable. The game slows down it's pace and focusses on the story, which turns out to be quite interesting. I wish Bioshock Infinite implemented more of it's story in between the runnin' and gunnin'. This would have made the game much less boring to play and would have made me enjoy it a tad bit more. Unfortunately, it didn't. 


Bioshock Infinite: 4.5

fun gameplay, though the ending is a cop out, just let me shoot the guy

Este juego fue pendiente en mi lista. tengo los originales  Bioshock 1 y 2 en dvd gastados en alguna parte. 
Complete la saga y voy a terminar todos los bioshock remasterizado.
No se si hay algo como esta historia de otras compaÃ±Ã­as tengo fe en algunos titulos. recuerdo horas sin cansarme de jugar pero el lore persiste, tengo que mantener la fe en que se saque la 4ta parte.

Fun game, especially how it references back to the original BioShock in many ways. It was nice to hear some of the same machine merchant voice lines every so often. 

My biggest gripe about this game is not being able to manually save. I'd be entering a new area and just staring at the top right corner waiting for an autosave when I had to get off to go do stuff. Hated that aspect. And then trying to replay from checkpoints to get a clean loop would suck because I'd have to rewatch all the nonskippable cutscenes.

The DLC is fun. Really like Clash in the Clouds, despite it being so hard I doubt I can 100% it. But it is cool how you buy unused models, roughdrafts, auditions with the extra money you collect in CitC.
Burial at sea is cool, especially fully seeing and interacting the original machine merchants. (I say this because its been years since I've played the original BioShock, but the voice lines are engraved in my mind)

Overall, fun game. Would recommend

Edit: After playing Burial at Sea Episode 2, I still enjoy it. It was weird, though. The DLC is a stealth game. Still fun, and a nice change of pace. Just wasn't expecting that.
Goooooood, diferente a las 2 entregas anteriores pero sin duda el mejor de la saga
one of the greatest stories i've ever seen

Fun game! I liked it significantly better than the other 2. 

The follower/companion system was the best and most refined of any game I've ever played. Elizabeth never got in your way, she would often lead you toward the objective all on her own, she interacted with the environment and had plenty of unique dialogue. She was actually helpful and could perform skills necessary for game progress. 

Sorry, Lydia, we've got a new favorite companion now.

The game is decent and should only be bought in sale. This game is worse than both other Bioshock games, 
They removed the mechanics that made the original games great. (Minor spoilers for the original games).

Negatives: 
* Hacking is now a "plasmid" / "vigor" and does not feel rewarding at all. 
* There is only one ending which is almost non-effected by your actions. 
* 2 Weapon slots is incredibly annoying and only causes me to not experiment with strategies.
* The first two games had side objectives (the little/big sisters), this game has only a bit of exploring.
* Autosave is bad/unstable, sometimes it saves 2 times per minute, sometimes it saves once 30 minutes. 

Positives: 
* The game looks absolutely stunning for its age and can almost be a next gen game with its visuals. 
* The new grappling hook is very fun to use.
* Although worse than the first two, the combat is still pretty good.

Dogshit story, predictable gameplay, elizabeth is a sketchy copout mechanic and grapple combat is stupid. Daisy Fitzroy is the lamest form of Black representation I've ever came across in a video game (the bar is so stupidly low) and it's sickening the leader of a revolutionary uprising was paralleled to basically a Henry Ford that creates magical drugs (because she has a weird obsession with... killing white children?). I don't want to finish this dogshit game and I hope no one ever looks at this as a legitimate example of a video game. It gets predictable fast and all of the attention put in the first ~3 hours of gameplay vanishes after that.
